titleStmt.title: Adieu for the present and The bearer Mr. Walt Whitman
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: As the fragmentary draft letter of introduction on the reverse must have been written shortly after Whitman's arrival in Washington in late 1862, this manuscript likely dates from 1863.
The following are responsible for particular readings or for changes to this file, as noted: Ashley Lawson Tim Jackson Brett Barney Elizabeth Lorang

corrections made based on additional review by KP, BB, and EL

div1.head: AAdieu for the present,
div1.p:
I must close for the pressent, although I see my hurried pen has
not hardly
begun to open upon the cas cases and suggestions I have to give, from my daily observation in the hospitals. To the rsad but rich mine there opened I shall soon return, in the and give you, reader, another letter.

del.p: The bearer Mr. Walt Whitman, a literary man of distinction, is from Brooklyn, New York. He desires employment as a clerk in the departments, or in any way in which he can be serviceable to the government. I commend him to the favorable consideration of any of the heads of departments who may need his services.
